text: In enzymology, a 1,2-dihydroxy-6-methylcyclohexa-3,5-dienecarboxylate dehydrogenase () is an enzyme that catalyzes the chemical reaction :1,2-dihydroxy-6-methylcyclohexa-3,5-dienecarboxylate + NAD \rightleftharpoons 3-methylcatechol + NADH + CO Thus, the two substrates of this enzyme are 1,2-dihydroxy-6-methylcyclohexa-3,5-dienecarboxylate and NAD, whereas its 3 products are 3-methylcatechol, NADH, and CO. This enzyme belongs to the family of oxidoreductases, specifically those acting on the CH-CH group of donor with NAD+ or NADP+ as acceptor. The systematic name of this enzyme class is 1,2-dihydroxy-6-methylcyclohexa-3,5-dienecarboxylate:NAD+ oxidoreductase (decarboxylating). This enzyme participates in toluene and xylene degradation. ==References== * Category:EC 1.3.1 Category:NADH-dependent enzymes Category:Enzymes of unknown structure
title: 1,2-dihydroxy-6-methylcyclohexa-3,5-dienecarboxylate dehydrogenase
